content: Would anyone object to a new notation for docs#ext_chart_at? They are quite a pain to type repetitively when working with manifolds. I propose ğ“”(I, x) to mean ext_chart_at I x, where the script E is entered with \MCE.
PR #17294 shows the effect of the new notation for ext_chart_at.

I haven't found ext_chart_at particularly annoying to write myself, so I'm neutral towards this proposal.
If we do this, do we want similar notation for chart_at?

• ğ“”(I, x) is much shorter, allowing formulas involving them to look like their regular mathematical counterparts. For me, it has made reading and thinking about these formulas much quicker.
  • I find myself going back and adding parentheses to ext_chart_at I x all the time when I need to append .symm, .source, .target. Writing ğ“”(I, x) would eliminate the need for this decision.
  • The notation ğ“ for nhds seems like a negative improvement (5 keystrokes instead of 4 including shift key) compared to ğ“” for ext_chart_at (5 instead of 14).
As for chart_at, I guess a natural choice would be ğ“’ (\MCC), but it looks so darn similar to ğ“”.
One alternative proposal would be to use ğ“’(H, x) (script C) for chart_at and eğ“’(I, x) or ğ“’â‚‘(I, x) for ext_chart_at (also script C).
If you just want this for files you're writing you can use local notation, this trick (or a local abbreviation) is used several times in mathlib to save typing
Not everything is about saving keystrokes. We use ğ“ in mathlib because it is commonly used notation for neighborhoods.
Winston, the neighborhood notation does save key, you only need to type \nh to trigger it.
I suppose a local notation is sufficient for my use. Thanks for the comments!
